Dear Ms. Klinski:
Attached is an amended Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility
completed on 05/24/21. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required.
It should be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of
the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of
this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 For repeat violations, note why the previous corrective action plan failed.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a six-month provisional license will
be issued as recommended in SIR 2021C0103016. If you do not agree to a provisional
license or fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4111 Job description.
An institution shall provide a job description for each staff position
that identifies rules, required qualifications, and lines of authority.
Three of 39 new employee files reviewed did not contain a job description. REPEAT
VIOLATION, Renewal Report, 07/14/20, and corresponding CAP, 07/14/20, and
Interim Report, 08/20/19, and corresponding CAP, 09/05/19. The facility must
identify why the previous CAPs failed and how they will ensure compliance.
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each employee
and
shall include documentation of all of the following information prior
to employment or at the time specified in this rule:
(a) Name.
(b) A true copy of verification of education from an accredited
college or university where minimum education requirements are
specified by rule.
(c) Verification of high school diploma or GED when specified
by rule.
(d) Work history.
(e) Three dated references which are obtained prior to
employment from persons unrelated to the employee and which
are less than 12 months old.
(f) A record of any convictions other than minor traffic
violations from either of the following entities:
(i) Directly from the Michigan state police or the equivalent
state law enforcement agency, Canadian province, or other
country where the person usually resides or has resided in the
previous 5 years.
(ii) From an entity accessing either Michigan state police
records or equivalent state, Canadian provincial, or other country
law enforcement agency where the person usually resides or has
resided in the previous 5 years.
(g) If the employee has criminal convictions, the institution
shall complete a written evaluation of the convictions that
addresses the nature of the conviction, the length of time since
the conviction, and the relationship of the conviction to regulated
4

activity for the purpose of determining suitability for employment
in the institution.
(i) Documentation from the Michigan department of human
services, the equivalent state or Canadian provincial agency, or
equivalent agency in the country where the person usually
resides, that the person has not been determined to be a
perpetrator of child abuse or child neglect. The documentation
shall be completed not more than 30 days prior to the start of
employment and every 12 months thereafter.
(j) A written evaluation of the employee's performance within
30 days of the completion of the probationary period or within 180
days, whichever is less, and a written evaluation of the
employee’s performance annually thereafter.
(c) 24 of 39 new employee files and one intern file did not have documentation of
education. REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal Report, 07/14/20, and corresponding
CAP, 07/14/20. The facility must identify why the previous CAP failed and how
they will ensure compliance.
(d) Nine of 39 new employee files and one intern file did not contain a work history,
or the information was blank.
(e) Seven of 38 new employee files and one intern file did not contain three dated
references completed within 12 months of hire.
(f) 14 new employee files and two intern files did not contain criminal history
clearances (one intern file required out of state clearance). An additional four new
employee files contained criminal history clearances, but they were completed after
hire. These must be completed with the CAP submission. REPEAT VIOLATION,
Renewal Report, 07/14/20, and corresponding CAP, 07/14/20. The facility must
identify why the previous CAP failed and how they will ensure compliance.
(g) One applicable new employee file, reviewed for criminal conviction, contained a
form that explained the conviction, but it was not signed by any agency
administrator, only the employee.
(i) 14 new employee files and two intern files did not contain central registry
clearances (one intern file required out of state clearance). An additional three new
employee files contained central registry clearances, but they were completed after
hire. Five of six existing employee files reviewed did not contain annual central
registry clearances. These must be completed with the CAP submission. REPEAT
VIOLATION, Renewal Report, 07/14/20, and corresponding CAP, 07/14/20, and
Interim Report, 08/20/19, and corresponding CAP, 09/05/19. The facility must
identify why the previous CAPs failed and how they will ensure compliance.
(j) Two of two applicable new employee files did not contain probationary
performance evaluations. Four of six existing employee files were missing annual
performance evaluations and an additional one was late. REPEAT VIOLATION,
Renewal Report, 07/14/20, and corresponding CAP, 07/14/20. The facility must
identify why the previous CAP failed and how they will ensure compliance.
5

R 400.4114 Tuberculosis screening for employees and volunteers.
The licensee shall document, prior to employment, that each
employee and volunteer who has contact with residents 4 or more
hours per week for more than 2 consecutive weeks is free from
communicable tuberculosis. Freedom from communicable
tuberculosis shall be verified within the 1-year period before
employment and shall be verified every 1 year after the last
verification or prior to the expiration of the current verification.
18 employee and intern files were found to have missing or late tuberculosis
screening. REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal Report, 07/14/20, and corresponding
CAP, 07/14/20, and Interim Report, 08/20/19, and corresponding CAP, 09/05/19.
The facility must identify why the previous CAPs failed and how they will
ensure compliance.
R 400.4128 Initial staff orientation and ongoing staff training.
(3) The licensee shall document that each staff person whose
function is covered by these rules has participated in a minimum
of 50 clock hours of planned training within the first year of
employment and a minimum of 25 clock hours of training annually
thereafter related to the employee’s job function. At least 16 of the
50 hours provided in the first year shall be orientation provided
prior to the assumption of duties.
Five of 39 new employee files did not contain documentation of 16 hours of
orientation prior to the assumption of duties. Three of six existing employee files did
not contain documentation of 25 annual hours of training.
R 400.4150 Incident reporting.
(1) Any incident resulting in serious injury of a resident or illness
requiring inpatient hospitalization, shall be reported to the parent/
legal guardian, responsible referring agency, and the licensing
authority as soon as possible, but not more than 24 hours after
the incident.
6

There was an incident of suicide attempt by a youth, which was investigated in SIR
2021C0108025. After the completion of the SIR, this incident was administratively
reviewed by DCWL and DHHS and it was noted that there was an additional report
that that the facility did not notify the family of the youth’s suicide attempt. This
allegation of family notification was not reported to DCWL during the investigation,
so was not addressed at the time. The facility was cited in this investigation for R
109 as they did not write an incident report as required by their own policy. In
response to the family notification, the facility stated that they did not have to advise
the family of a suicide attempt, however, an incident like this would fall under
subsection 1 of this rule. The facility must include a revised policy as part of their
CAP that includes family notification, along with the other required notifications
outlined in the rule, in situations of suicide attempts, as this is considered serious
injury by nature of the event.
R 400.4152 Initial documentation.
At the time of admission, all of the following shall be in the
resident's case record:
(f) Documentation of legal right to provide care.
One of six current youth files did not contain documentation of legal right to provide
care. A court order was provided by the facility, but it did not specify placement at
the facility and authorize services.
R 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; initial treatment plan.
(3) The initial treatment plan shall include all of the following:
(b) Plans for parent and child visitation.
One of two applicable resident files did not address plans for parent child visitation in
the initial treatment plan.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements reviewed.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract/Policy violation. Please
note that there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:

RFCJJ Contract Oct 17: Prison Rape Elimination Act & Sexual Abuse
Prevention & Response Overview.
Four of 39 new/rehired employees did not have current documentation of PREA
training. One of six existing employees PREA training was over a year old. One
of two interns did not have a file to verify the training.
RFCJJ Contract Oct 17: Annual Trauma Focused Training
38 of 43 applicable employee files reviewed did not document annual trauma
training.
RFCJJ Contract Oct 17: AWOLP/escape Procedures Training
43 of 43 applicable employee files reviewed did not document quarterly AWOLP
training.
RFCJJ Contract Oct 17 Individual Service Agreement
One of three applicable resident files contained an Individual Service Agreement
that was not signed by the facility.
RFCJJ 2.10.b Standardized Assessment Tools: Casey Life Skills
Assessment
Three of three applicable resident files contained documentation that an initial
Casey Life Skills Assessment was completed but the records were not dated to
confirm timeframe. Additionally, there was no documentation of ongoing
assessments being completed. Per the facility ACE Casey Life Skills Policy, the
Casey Life Skills are given within 30 days of enrollment and when the student
reaches stage 6 of the program or one year - whichever comes first. The facility
must begin to provide documentation of the completion of the assessments
inclusive of the dates to be compliant.
RFCJJ Contract Oct 17: Attachment A.2 Weekly Individual Therapy
Three of three applicable resident files reviewed contained plans that indicated
individual therapy occurred weekly. This is consistent with resident interviews.
RFCJJ Contract Oct 17: Attachment A.3 Standardized Assessment Tool:
Juvenile Justice Sexually Reactive Residential Program, the youth’s overall
progress shall be assessed using the Estimate of Risk of Adolescent
Sexual Offense Recidivism Version 2 (ERASOR Version 2.0) or Juvenile
Sex Offender Assessment Protocol (J-SOAP II).
One applicable resident file did not contain the required assessment tool.
8

RFCJJ Contract Oct 17: 2.10.f.1-2 Supervisor signature
One of three applicable resident files was found not to have uploaded the treatment
plan signature page within the 14 days permitted.
DHHS Policy JR2 203-YOUTH ORIENTATION
One applicable resident file was not provided orientation until after two weeks of
entering the program. It was reported that youth are on quarantine for two weeks
upon admission, however, the facility must devise a way to ensure that the new
residents are fully oriented to the facility program, rules, grievance process, etc.,
per the policy requirement of 24 hours, unless there are extenuating
circumstances.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R 150
The agency was advised to ensure all required parties are notified in the event of an
AWOLP. This includes when youth are out of the facility on home passes and go
AWOLP from there. It is recommended that this is documented on the AWOLP
incident report for verification purposes.
R 152
The agency is advised to ensure all initial documentation, including documentation of
legal right to provide care and provision of grievance procedures, at the time of
admission.
R 166
The agency is advised to clearly document the services to be provided to youth after
discharge on the discharge plans. The documentation of aftercare contacts must be
provided in the file as well.
RFCJJ Contract Oct 17: Medical and Dental Care-Documentation in MiSACWIS
The facility is advised to ensure timely uploading of medical and dental documents (5
days).
RFCJJ Contract Oct 17 Attachment A.2 Psychiatric Consultation
The facility is advised to ensure timely completion of initial psychiatric consultation
after admission (15 days).
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
9

Consultation was provided regarding employee files and the need to increase
monitoring and internal audits to ensure proper documentation on an ongoing basis.
Additionally, it is recommended that the facility maintain up to date training logs
instead of individually signed training forms. While the individually signed forms are
important to document receipt of trainings, the cumulative trainings should be updated
on a log regularly.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There was one incident of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period. This was investigated by both DCWL (SIR 2021C0108004) and
DHHS and significantly contributed to the facility’s current first provisional license
status. During this incident, the youth was improperly restrained and transported,
which resulted in significant injuries. The CAP indicated a focus of training through
2021 with a focus on transport. This is still ongoing at this time and will continue to be
monitored. The CAP outlined that one staff was terminated and two others received
supervision and verbal counseling. The facility was not able to provide documentation
for one of these counseling memorandums due to that staff’s supervisor leaving the
facility. This will need to be addressed by another supervisor to ensure compliance
with the CAP. Ongoing supervision of the two employees has been informal per the
Director. Monthly unannounced onsite visits have occurred, and youth have not
reported any excessive, aggressive, or physical methods of discipline or punishment.
Restraints are reported to be done appropriately by the youth.
There was one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period. This was investigated by DCWL in Special Investigation
2021C0201024, and the facility was cited for use of corporal punishment as
discipline. Staff retraining was outlined in the CAP. Verification of the trainings will
occur in June 2021 to allow the facility time to provide the documentation. Monthly
unannounced onsite visits have occurred, and youth have not reported any
excessive, unjustified, aggressive, or physical methods of discipline or punishment.
Restraints are reported to be done appropriately per the youth.
The facility has submitted seven acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period. This provisional review period found
the following special investigations were completed, requiring CAPs.
 2021C0219022: This investigation cited R 127(2) Staff to resident ratio. The
facility submitted a CAP and ratio has been monitored ongoing during monthly
onsite visits. The facility has been found in compliance with the rule and their
CAP.
 2021C0201024: A summary of this investigation is noted above related to use
of corporal punishment.
 2021C0201016: This investigation cited R 126 Sufficiency of Staff due to a
youth being repeatedly hit by peers with staff on duty. This occurred over time
10

and on different Pods. It was concluded that the staff was not providing for the
protection and supervision of this youth. The facility submitted a CAP included
plans for maintaining ratios and for increased quarterly training of staff. This
CAP will continue to be monitored as it was just implemented in March 2021.
During monthly unannounced visits, the facility has been compliant with ratio
and no youth have reported any safety related concerns.
 2021C0108025: This investigation cited R 109(1)(c) for not following their own
policy related to incident reporting. In this case, a youth attempted suicide and
the facility staff did not write an incident report before leaving their shift. The
CAP indicated staff retraining. This will be monitored for compliance in June
2021 to allow the facility time to provide documentation for verification of
completion.
 2021C0108010: This investigation found the facility in noncompliance of R
407(1) as a youth was in a bedroom with a malfunctioning lock. The issue was
known to the staff and therapist, but the youth remained in the room. The
facility CAP noted that youth will not be permitted to remain in rooms with
malfunctioning locks, and maintenance issues will be discussed during
meetings, and maintenance request forms will be readily available to staff. The
facility was not compliant with this CAP as another investigation,
2021C0103016, found youth and staff knew that youth could “pop” open some
bedrooms on Pod H and youth remained in those rooms. This resulted in the
facility being recommended for a second provisional license as outlined below.
 2021C0108005: This investigation cited R 127(2) for noncompliance with ratio,
and R 159(2) for a resident restraining other youth to protect the one staff on
shift. The facility submitted a CAP and ratio has been monitored ongoing
during monthly onsite visits. The facility has been found in compliance with the
rule and their CAP for ratio.
 2021C0108004: A summary of this investigation is noted above related to
substantiated child abuse/neglect. A first provisional license was implemented
after this investigation.
It is notable that there are currently two completed investigations, 2021C0103018 and
2021C0103016, with pending CAPs. Both investigations have violations and have
resulted in the facility being recommended for a Second Provisional License. SIR
2021C0103016 had violations for R 109(1)(c) due to staff sleeping during shift, R
112(4) as the staff knew youth could “pop” bedroom locks open and did not ensure
safety and supervision, and a violation of R 407(1) related to the bedroom locks on
Pod H being able to be “popped” open by youth which creates a significant security
and safety risk. SIR 2021C0103018 cited the facility for R 109(1)(c) for not following
their policy on suicide precautions. This is a similar citation as 2021C0108025 as a
youth attempted suicide by wrapping a shirt around his neck and the staff had to
physically remove it. This staff did not document the incident on an incident report.
11

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, I continue to recommend that the agency license
be modified to a Second Provisional license as recommended in Special Investigation
Report 2021C0103016.
